グランブルーファンタジーは、非常に充実したコンテンツを備えた素晴らしいRPGです。しかし、いくつか問題点も抱えています。このゲームがどのようなものなのか、詳しく説明します。

ゲームプレイ：
このゲームのゲームプレイは、「テイルズ オブ アライズ」と「モンスターハンター」シリーズを融合させたような感じですね。戦闘は「テイルズ オブ アリエス」を彷彿とさせますが、ゲームシステムは「モンスターハンター」シリーズそのもの。一体何を目的にプレイしているのでしょうか？戦闘に関しては、テイルズ オブ アライズのように、完璧な回避、呪文の詠唱、フィニッシュムーブを一人でもグループでも繰り出せるので、テイルズ オブ アライズをプレイしていれば、私の言いたいことがお分かりいただけると思います。そして、先ほども触れた機能についてですが、モンスターハンターのようにボスを倒すか、ちょっとした敵を倒すかのどちらかです。アイテムや印章はモンスターハンターのように新しい武器を作るためのアイテム機能ですが、このゲームには防御力を高めるための防具がありません。防御力を高めるには、プレイヤーはチャーターをレベルアップするか、適切な印章を見つける必要があります。そうそう、2つほど付け加えておきたいことがあります。まず、モンスターハンターのように異なる武器を使うのが楽しいですが、このゲームではキャラクターごとに動きが異なるため、異なるキャラクターを使う必要があります。そして、印章はモンスターハンターの宝石のように、スキルを追加したり強化したりするためのものです。

ストーリー：
ストーリーについては何も言えませんが、このゲームのストーリーはまあまあといったところです。悪くはないですが、良いわけでもありません。まあまあといったところです。典型的な友情の物語です。悪者から仲間を救出するストーリー。私の記憶が正しければ、ストーリーは約12時間です。

コンテンツ：
ええと、このゲームのコンテンツは、スーパーラスボスを倒すのに本気で取り組めば100時間くらいかかると思いますが、正直言って、モンスターハンターのベースコンテンツよりもコンテンツが少なめに感じます。

マルチプレイ/オンライン：
マルチプレイに関しては、特にJPとKRのプレイヤーを中心に、アクティブなプレイヤーはまだ見つかりますが、ほとんどのプレイヤーは既にレベルマックスで圧倒的な強さを誇っているので、初心者プレイヤーを見つけるのは難しいです。なので、個人的には、マルチプレイはエンドコンテンツで楽しめると思います。

バグと不具合:
バグかどうかは分かりませんが、GPUが熱くなり、プレイヤーがNPCに近づいたり話しかけたりするたびにフレームレートが低下します。なぜか、激しい戦闘シーンのある戦闘ゾーンに入るとGPUは熱くならず、ゲームプレイには問題ない状態です。問題はプレイヤーがNPCに近づいたり話しかけたりした時に発生します。

総合的に:

このゲームは素晴らしいので、定価でも割引価格でもお勧めします。ただし、マルチプレイヤーのためにロビーで誰かを見つけることを期待しているなら、それでも見つかります。しかし、前述したように、ほとんどの人は既にエンドゲームで既に登場しています。ストーリーはまあまあで、良くも悪くもありません。このゲームの面白さはボスや個性的なプレイアブルキャラクターにあります。グラフィックは良好で、モデルや呪文、攻撃、フィニッシュムーブのエフェクトは素晴らしく、NPCに近づいたり話しかけたりするとフレームレートが低下し、GPUが熱くなるというバグも忘れてはいけません

One of the best combat systems I've ever experienced in an Action RPG. Single Player and Multiplayer, this game delivers. Let me explain why.

Every character in the game has a unique mechanic that gives them identity and win Condition. The main character, "Danchou" is geared for team support, but also chains combo finishers to massively increase skill damage. Carlotta's goal relies on her staying on the enemy and delivering constant damage, using her parry frames frames, gap closers and defensive skills to stay in the enemies face. Narmaya is far more technical, managing her butterfly resource and different stance combos and self buffs to optimize her damage.

The game can be compared to the Monster Hunter Series in terms of gameplay variety if you consider each character a "weapon"

Many Action RPGs fall into a "Damage sponge enemy" trope where the boss doesn't budge outside of a stagger meter. Forcing your party to dance around its attacks while you look for openings to land yours. Challenging but not Interactive. Relink circumvents that with both the titular "Link System" and the games mechanic for ultimate skills : Skybound Arts.

Link Attacks stagger the enemy when used and utilize multiplayer , encouraging everyone to join in the attack. When used enough times and the meter hits 100% Link Time is activated. This slows down time, Applying multiple buffs, including character specific ones. Giving you the opportunity to go wild on the enemy with optimal dps rotations.

Skybound Arts can be used any time your meter is full , but is best used when everyone has close to full meter. This attack completely interrupts the enemy's current attack, and can be chained together to optimize the damage. A full 4 player burst adds a huge damage bonus.

Coordinating these mechanics for regular use already adds a layer of depth to combat. the push and pull of fights of enemies going into "Overdrive" where they become hyper aggressive, and the pull of SBA and Link Attacks pulling the advantage state back to the player is extremely satisfying and makes combat much more hype.

At HIGHER levels of play, link attacks and SBAs can be optimized further: SBAs can be staggered between uses to give the party more downtime to damage a stunned monster. Link Attacks AND SBAs, can also be saved for the right time to immediately chunk through a bosses overdrive meter. OR interrupt a particularly difficult attack or mechanic. There is a HUGE amount of space for expression, coordination and enemy knowledge to come together.

All of this comes together to create what is one of the BEST combat systems I've ever played in an Action RPG, as a fan of them since the SNES era, This ranks in my top 10 of all time.

The game does have its flaws, however. I think the post release endgame falls flat, with bosses falling into the stressful "One hit KO" hyper aggressive battle style. Forcing players to stack lots of guts and anti one shot sigils. This ruins the build variety we get to enjoy up until this late game.

I also do not like the Terminus weapons, they become hyper centralizing and locks people into a low HP cap to meet dps, the entertaining build variety takes a back seat to a very limiting game direction. Challenging? Yes, but expression is the spice of the game and unfortunately, it drops the ball here.

Despite all my love for the game, I'm more interested in replaying a low level game instead of conquering the unforgiving Lucilius and the exhausting amount of 1 shot and wipe mechanics. It's a Superboss, and not a necessary part of the core game experience. So it can be forgiven.

Overall, this game is absolutely worth experiencing. The Story is not ground breaking but full of hype music, battle scenes, and setpiece moments. it's almost like a playable action movie. For a multiplayer focused action game? I'd rather be entertained through a 20 hour action filled main campaign, than be forced to sit through tons of world building cutscenes in a single player focused game like Final Fantasy 16. It works for what it is.

It may not be a live service, but the fact that it isn't is WHY it works so well, without that incentive to make money, the devs are not pressured to monetize and frustrate players to keep the money coming. What we are left with is an amazing experience you'll easily get 100+ hours out of, and possibly more should you decided to play more characters and really master the game.

Thank you very much for reading.

Granblue Fantasy: Relink is a spin off of the mobile game Granblue Fantasy, but you don’t need to know the original in order to understand it. There are no microtransactions, loot boxes, premium currencies, or any of the usual gacha systems. This is a full-fledged action RPG where character and equipment progression come entirely from playing (but you can still buy really overpriced DLC's to make your game easier) ((Remember to not buy character DLC, you can get all characters for free in game, DLC basically give you one special sigil that slightly upgrades that certain character))

The biggest strength of Relink is its combat system. It is dynamic and very fluid, somewhat similar to Nier: Automata or Devil May Cry, but with a stronger team focus. You can play as more than twenty different characters (I love you, Tweyen), each with their own style, weapons, attack animations and abilities. Every battle feels a bit different (unless you're grinding the endgame quests, especially the Bahamut fight for Ascended weapons, then God bless you). The Skybound Arts and linked attacks system is especially fun, particularly in co-op mode (unfortunately I wasn't able to experience it myself at all due to lack of playerbase)

Exploration and character progression are also well thought out. Characters grow through missions and upgrades made to them really make a difference. New weapons and sigils have a clear impact. The problem starts later in the game, when the grind becomes heavy and relies on repeating the same missions over and over to get single materials for upgrades. Some weapons or items require combining and farming extremely rare drops multiple times, which can get discouraging. The fun starts to fade when you realize you have to spend hours just to slightly increase one character’s damage. The overall progression structure won’t appeal to everyone. It can feel too stretched out and artificially slowed down. On the other hand, if you enjoy games with long endgames and detailed character development, that is where the real fun begins.

The story is a classic anime style fantasy adventure, full of dialogue, emotional scenes, and well acted cutscenes, but without many surprises. If you have watched even one anime about a group of heroes on a quest or simply some isekai slop, you already know what to expect. The characters are likable but predictable, and the story completely loses focus near the end. The last few chapters feel messy and repetitive. You think the story is over, but then another fight starts, and then another, and it keeps going. After chapter seven, it starts to fall apart, and it’s hard to stay invested. On the other hand, the world looks amazing. Locations are colorful and full of detail. Great voice acting and music keep the atmosphere strong even when the plot doesn’t.

From a technical standpoint, Relink is a very solid game. It runs smoothly, I didn’t experience crashes or bugs even after dozens of hours. The graphics are beautiful, animations are fluid and on PC everything performs perfectly. The main campaign takes around twenty hours, but the real content lies in the endgame, with hundreds of missions, character upgrades, better gear and 54 achievements that will make you question your life choices. 

Overall, I’d say the game is impressive in how complete and polished it feels, especially for something based on a gacha series. The combat, visuals, and smooth performance make it easy to recommend. The story, balance, and late game grind are weaker points. In short: a great game if you enjoy combat and grinding, but most improtantly, always get it on a sale. You won't be able to experience 100% of it due to game no longer having live updates and active playerbase.

[h2] A gorgeous game hidden beneath a mountain of UI [/h2] 

Initial impressions were decent. Game felt smooth, graphics and art style are excellent and the character controls well. Dialogue was sappy but tolerable. 

However, two aspects killed the experience for me before it properly even began. 

Firstly, the limited customization for controls. I always rebind dodge to the B / Circle button on a controller, and the default binding for dodge in this game is RT. No big deal, just change it to a different button, right? Wrong. There are three preset options for controls, and if I wanted dodge on B, it convoluted the skill casting controls (to a clunky combination of Y+Shoulder buttons instead of RB + Face buttons) and attacks were moved to shoulder buttons as well. I could have perhaps gotten used to this if it wasn't for the second point that made me ALT + F4 after beating the first boss of the game. 

Without a hint of exaggeration, this game has the worst UI bloat I have ever seen before. And the only customization given to you is the option to disable the map.. that's it, nothing else. When the party members joined in during the boss battle, I knew I couldn't play this game further. 

In no particular order you have: 
[olist]
    [*]Boss healthbar on the top of the screen. Not even at the very top, it's offset from the edge of the screen in a way that leaves around 10% empty space at the top of it, leaving less room for the actual game and making things feel more cluttered for no reason. 
    [*]Permanent quest objective displayed at all times at the top right of the screen, again placed at an annoying offset that leaves wasted space above it. 
    [*]Enormous, glowing percentage number on the middle right of the screen that says "LINK X%", embellished with sparkles and unnecessary art around it. Directly below it are lists of team members whom it can be used with, further cluttering the screen. 
    [*]Hideously massive list of controls on the bottom right of the screen, showing you a permanent tutorial on how to attack, jump, dodge and so on. Even sprinting and pause menu is permanently visible for some reason. This is something that you can not turn off, and it takes a significant chunk of an already cluttered screen. 
    [*]An indicator directly next to your character, showing some kind of a level that your skill has reached. This font is big enough that it's 15-20% as big as your character is, with zero transparency to it. I have never seen a more obnoxious UI element in a game before, so that's cool. 
    [*]Mandatory damage numbers that of course can not be edited or turned off.
    [*]Even the lock-on icon is a massive circle instead of a relatively innocuous dot or a similar icon like most games use. 
    [*]On the bottom-left there's further instructions on how to guard and lock-on. Of course offset about 10% from the side so as to constrict everything nice and tight. Next to it is a permanent, glowing list of consumables for your viewing convenience. 
    [*]And the absolute worst offender of them all, the teammate list. This takes up the top-left of the screen, stretching down vertically all the way to the middle of the screen. It lists out every single team member's health, buffs, icon, element type and some kind of an orange bar. It is extremely distracting and annoying to look at. It even lists out the blue-haired girl as "GUEST" at the very bottom because apparently that's important information for us to see during battle. 
[/olist] 

I'm willing to tolerate annoying UI elements to a degree, but this game goes above and beyond with its incessant UI bloat. People make fun of ubisoft games for obnoxious UI, but at least in those games you can turn off most UI elements as you please. There is such a beautiful, fun game here but unfortunately the developers have done their very best to hide as much of it as humanly possible.

Unfortunately, the story mode is short and not that engaging, and most online raids or dungeons are already empty (you can party with AI). The game relies heavily on grinding — weapons, characters, and materials — which can feel repetitive.

In short: A technical and artistic marvel with fairly typical but tight action-JRPG combat, held back by some tedious boss design, RNG, and grind.

The graphics, and technical implementation are truly awesome. It puts most other modern games to shame, running 120fps easily on several generation old desktop hardware. It looks great, even for being an "anime game". My one graphical complaint is the ridiculous number of attack effects all over the screen, particularly on harder difficulties and some bosses. Makes it almost impossible to tell when/if you should dodge and attack because of the visual noise.

The number of characters is impressive and most of them feel pretty unique. Overall, unless you want a really grindy action-JRPG with some light hints of Monster Hunter style farming, this is a pass at the normal price, and a soft recommend on a deep sale.

The combat system is pretty fun, if a bit mindless at its core. I tried a few characters and they all ended up boiling down to the same fundamentals: repeat the 'best' combo chain for your character's gimmick until your resource is full, then dump all your damage, then repeat. On its own it does get boring pretty fast, and the swarm encounters in this game get very repetitive as a result. The boss fights though, are generally quite fun and well designed. There are a few nitpicks here too, an awkward forced camera angle on some attacks or the occasional poorly-telegraphed move, but they are really the highlight of this game and are overall pretty fun.

That's pretty much all the game has going for it though. As someone who wasn't familiar with the characters before playing this game, they seem bland and utterly one-dimensional. In 15 hours playing I never felt like I got to know any of them or really understand the dynamics between them. The story is also aggressively safe; I understand there's an audience for cozy and family friendly games but I feel this game drifts well past that into 'totally uninspired' territory. I cannot overstate how uninteresting the characters, story and wider world are.

Progression is also uninteresting. Since you can avoid pretty much all damage just by dodging correctly, optimization tends towards the classic 'more damage gooder'. Just max out your damage tree till you hit the cap for your current progression state, then put any extra points into defense till you hit the next section of the tree, repeat. None of the stats synergize in a way that's interesting either, they pretty much all function in a straightforward manner that works exactly like you would think at first glance. I wouldn't expect a game like this to have deep or meaningful build creation, but its worth noting how little is on offer here.

Maps in missions are also not interesting to navigate. As I said earlier, all the 'swarm' encounters are pretty boring and every map is filled to the brim with little treasures containing near-worthless pennies for you to run around and pick up. It really feels deeply unrewarding and chore-like.

In summary: If you don't care about the story, or already have a connection with the characters and world from other games, and are looking for a fast-paced third-person brawler this game is a fine pickup if you can get it on sale. Otherwise, I can't recommend it.
